Award.AwardTitle: Cyclic Dimeric GMP, a Novel Second Messenger in Bacteria: Molecular Mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyclic dimeric guanosine monophosphate, c-di-GMP, is a key molecule involved in the lifestyle switch in bacteria, from single motile cells to surface-attached multicellular communities (biofilms). c-di-GMP controls this lifestyle switch by affecting bacterial motility, adhesion to surfaces, synthesis of extracellular matrix, stress resistance, and virulence. Gaining mechanistic insights into how c-di-GMP functions is of fundamental importance in bacteriology. Currently, a glaring gap exists between the large numbers of enzymes involved in c-di-GMP synthesis and hydrolysis (several dozen in most proteobacteria) and the small numbers (low single digits) of known c-di-GMP receptors, or effector proteins. This gap indicates that many c-di-GMP receptors have escaped identification. The long-term objective of this project is to identify new c-di-GMP receptors and uncover molecular mechanisms through which they operate in a model bacterium, Escherichia coli. In this project, new c-di-GMP receptors will be identified by genetic means as well as by the affinity-based capture. Because c-di-GMP, like other second messengers, works though conserved molecular mechanisms, it is expected that the insights derived from E. coli will inform strategies on controlling behavior of various bacterial species of medical, agricultural, environmental and biotechnological significance.

The broader merit of this proposal lies in understanding the mechanisms that control bacterial behavior. This understanding is critical for designing pharmacological interventions that would allow us to manipulate bacteria in desirable ways. This project will offer interdisciplinary training opportunities in bioinformatics, bacterial genetics, protein-ligand biochemistry, and physiology to graduate and undergraduate students who will comprise the core research personnel. It will also provide research experiences to minority high school students enrolled in the Summer Research Apprenticeship Program. The project results will be presented at scientific meetings and published in research papers as well as in the articles for broader audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerned the identification and characterization of mechanisms by which bacteria adjust their lifestyles to a changing environment. At the center of decision-making processes in many bacteria lies the signaling molecule, cyclic dimeric guanosine monophosphate (c-di-GMP). Elevated intracellular c-di-GMP levels trigger the transition of motile bacteria to a sedentary lifestyle by promoting attachment to surfaces and formation of multicellular communities known as biofilms. Bacteria grown in biofilms secrete extracellular matrix components that protect them from desiccation and other environmental stresses. Sugar-based polymers known as exopolysaccharides  are common components of biofilm matrices. Bacterial biofilms are hard to eradicate using antibiotics. Most chronic diseases involve biofilms, which is a key reason for the difficulty in curing chronic bacterial infections. The goal of this project was to discover and understand novel molecular mechanisms through which c-di-GMP operates. Better mechanistic understanding is expected to lead to the development of the means to counteract c-di-GMP action, that is to prevent biofilm formation or enhance dissolution of preformed biofilms.

As a result of this project we have made several important advances in the field of c-di-GMP signaling. We have identified a novel c-di-GMP receptor (BcsE) that controls synthesis of the exopolysaccharide cellulose, a protective matrix of E. coli and Salmonella, important for their survival in the environment and inside mammalian cells. This was done in collaboration with the group of Ute Römling (Karolinska Institute, Sweden) and Michael Galperin (NCBI, NIH). We have deciphered a specific region (protein domain), involved in c-di-GMP binding, which now allows researchers to identify c-di-GMP-binding regions in other species. We revealed an unexpected complexity in cellulose regulation that involves two-tiered c-di-GMP control of cellulose synthesis. We hypothesize that this mechanism prevents bacteria from premature commitment to biofilm formation. In another direction, we have uncovered a new mechanism controlling production of capsular polysaccharide, a different protective matrix component in E. coli. This was done in collaboration with Römling and Alan Wolfe (Loyola University of Chicago). To better understand mechanisms of c-di-GMP action, it is desirable to have the means to modulate c-di-GMP levels in bacteria. To enable such control, we have engineered a protein that synthesizes c-di-GMP in response to red/infrared light and a protein that degrades c-di-GMP in response to blue light. By carefully adjusting production of this light-activated synthase and a c-di-GMP-degrading enzyme, we engineered a system to control c-di-GMP levels with high spatiotemporal resolution. This system will allow researchers to gain deeper insights into c-di-GMP-dependent regulation of motility, biofilm formation and dissolution, as well as other aspects of bacterial decision making.

In addition to these studies, we have leveraged the resources of this grant to gain new insights into c-di-GMP signaling mechanisms in the bacterial predator Bdellovibrio (with Liz Sockett, University of Nottingham, U.K.), the beneficial soil bacterium Azospirillum (with Gladys Alexandre, University of Tennessee), the antibiotic–producing bacterium Streptomyces (with Jennifer Bennett, Juanita College) and the E. coli strain that colonizes the GI tract of cattle (with Christine Martin, Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique, France).
